AAC - Advanced Audio Coding is a lossy compression standard. AAC is a part of MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 specifications. It uses Modified Discrete Cosine Transform, achieving better quality than .mp3 format while keeping similar bitrate. 

While DCT is a coding process including quantization which is executed most significantly on high-frequency data components (not high-frequency sound parts) which humans ears are suppose to be less sensible for, the 'Modification' in DCT is an addition to DCT, a process of overlapping which is suppose to save some part of data that is being lost during pure DCT. 

AAC is a very flexible codec as it is able to achieve up to 96 kHz sampling rate and up 48 channels depending on the implementation, but using your smartphone and average bluetooth audio device you will gain decent (2-channel 44.1 kHz sampling frequency) audio quality.
